resource.chars:
<s>At the same time<\s> We have seen that the arrangement of the
foliation of Gneiss & Schist is in large flattish
arches, in which the dip is slight near the
central axis, & gradually encreases in inclination as we
recede from the centre till it becomes vertical
at <s>a certain<\s> the same distance on each side of the
centre: this arrangement is precisely analogous
to that of the cleavage of Slates which I first
described in 1846 & have found in all subsequent
observations to be the usual disposition of the
planes of cleavage. But this is very rarely
the position of the <s>beds<\s> <s>strata<\s> beds of an elevated district;
when stratified rocks have been <s>elevated<\s> raised into
an arch or a dome, the steepest inclination
of the beds is usually found near the axis
or point of elevation and the inclination
<u>diminishes<\u> as the distance from the disturbing
force <u>encreases<\u>. The contrary will un-
doubtedly be sometimes found, <s>but<\s> yet it is very
seldom that we see the distant beds dip
at a higher angle than those nearer to the
axis of disturbance. But this which is a rare
exception in planes of stratification is
almost the universal rule with cleavage
and foliation.
